title: 02. Things are not what they seem

slides.text: Practical men, who believe themselves to be quite exempt from any intellectual influences, are usually the slaves of some *defunct economist*.
slides.reflectionText: Keynes may have a point, but where do these *defunct economists* get their ideas from?
slides.reference: Keynes, J. M. (1936). *The general theory of employment, interest, and money.* Palgrave Macmillan.

slides.text: In fact, I'd go another step and say that we're usually slaves of some defunct *philosophers*. Some are not even philosophers, but figures of populism. Very often, we're under the influence of something we intuitively feel to be true, but haven't thorougly investigated what they meant in the context of their origins. Feelings can be deceiving - especially ones without the backing of careful reasoning.

The professional intellectuals are, in effect, the field agents of the army whose head or commander in chief is the philosopher. 

 And professional intellectuals are all those whose professions deal with the humanities, the studies of man as against the physical sciences. 

 The professional intellectuals ... carry to the rest of the culture, the rest of society, the philosophical premises, the ideas which have been defined by the philosopher. 

 They are the ones who determine the goals, the values, and the direction of a culture.
slides.reflectionText: Keynes may have a point, but where do these *defunct economists* get their ideas from?
slides.reference: Ayn Rand Institute. (2015). James McConnell Interviews Ayn Rand About the New Intellectual. *In YouTube*. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IeaAC832gG4
